message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The heavy vaginal bleeding in this teenage girl is likely due to anovulatory bleeding. Conjugated estrogen therapy can help stabilize the endometrium and control the bleeding. Tranexamic acid is used for heavy menstrual bleeding, but it is not the first-line treatment for this patient. Uterine artery embolization and uterine curettage are invasive procedures that are not necessary for this patient at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s heavy bleeding and irregular cycles suggest dysfunctional uterine bleeding, and the negative urine pregnancy test rules out ectopic pregnancy. Among the options, only conjugated estrogen therapy is used to stabilize the endometrial lining, regulate periods, and decrease bleeding in dysfunctional uterine bleeding.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has heavy vaginal bleeding with clots and irregular menstrual cycles, which suggest dysfunctional uterine bleeding. Conjugated estrogen therapy can help regulate menstrual cycles and reduce bleeding. Tranexamic acid and uterine artery embolization may be used for management of heavy menstrual bleeding but are not the first-line treatment. Uterine curettage may be necessary if the bleeding is due to underlying pathology, but this is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The heavy bleeding and passage of clots suggest dysfunctional uterine bleeding, which can be managed with oral contraceptives or estrogen therapy. Of the options listed, only Conjugated estrogen therapy is appropriate for this patient. Uterine curretage may be considered if the bleeding does not respond to medical therapy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The heavy menstrual bleeding suggests menorrhagia, which can be treated with Conjugated estrogen therapy to reduce the bleeding. Tranexamic acid can also be used. Uterine artery embolization or curretage are not appropriate unless there is a specific indication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The heavy bleeding and the irregular intervals suggest dysfunctional uterine bleeding. Conjugated estrogen therapy is used to stabilize the endometrium and stop bleeding in these cases. Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent that can also be used to treat heavy menstrual bleeding, but it is not a first-line option. Uterine artery embolization and uterine curettage are more invasive treatments reserved for severe cases or failed medical management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The heavy and prolonged vaginal bleeding suggests dysfunctional uterine bleeding. Conjugated estrogen therapy can help regulate menstrual cycles and decrease bleeding. Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent that can help decrease bleeding, but it does not address the underlying cause. Uterine artery embolization and uterine curettage are invasive procedures that are not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The heavy menstrual bleeding with clots suggests dysfunctional uterine bleeding, which is treated with hormonal therapy. Conjugated estrogen therapy is the most appropriate next step to manage this patient’s symptoms. Tranexamic acid is used to treat heavy menstrual bleeding, but it is not the first line of therapy. Uterine artery embolization and uterine curettage are invasive procedures and not necessary for this patient’s management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The heavy bleeding and irregular menstrual history suggest dysfunctional uterine bleeding (DUB). Conjugated estrogen therapy is used to stabilize the endometrium and control bleeding in DUB. Tranexamic acid and uterine artery embolization are not recommended as first-line therapy for DUB. Uterine curettage may be indicated for diagnosis but is not indicated as first-line therapy for DUB.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The heavy, irregular bleeding in a young adolescent with a negative pregnancy test suggests anovulatory bleeding. Conjugated estrogen therapy is appropriate for this patient population to help control the bleeding. Tranexamic acid and uterine artery embolization are not first-line treatments and uterine curretage is unnecessary.
